greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of 3-infinitary divisors of n: if n = Product p(i)^r(i) and d = Product p(i)^s(i), each s(i) has a digit a <= b in its ternary expansion everywhere that the corresponding r(i) has a digit b, then d is a 3-infinitary-divisor of n.
comment: Multiplicative: If e = sum d_k 3^k, then a(p^e) = prod (d_k+1). - _Christian G. Bower_, May 19 2005
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000

Frédéric Chyzak, Ivan Gutman, and Peter Paule, Predicting the number of hexagonal systems with 24 and 25 hexagons, Communications in Mathematical and Computer Chemistry (1999) No. 40, 139-151. See p. 141.
J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles [Broken link]
J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles [Via Internet Archive Wayback-Machine]
J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles [Cached copy, pdf file only]
Index entries for sequences computed from exponents in factorization of n
formula: a(1) = 1; for n > 1, a(n) = A006047(A067029(n)) * a(A028234(n)). [After _Christian G. Bower_'s 2005 comment.] - _Antti Karttunen_, May 28 2017
example: 2^3*3 is a 3-infinitary-divisor of 2^5*3^2 because 2^3*3 = 2^10*3^1 and 2^5*3^2 = 2^12*3^2 in ternary expanded power. All corresponding digits satisfy the condition. 1 <= 1, 0 <= 2, 1 <= 2.
maple: A038148 := proc(n) if n= 1 then 1; else ifa := ifactors(n)[2] ;
a := 1; for f in ifa do e := convert(op(2,f),base,3) ; a := a*mul(d+1,d=e) ; end do: end if; end proc:
mathematica: a[1] = 1; a[n_] := (k = 1; Do[k = k * Times @@ (IntegerDigits[f, 3] + 1), {f, FactorInteger[n][[All, 2]]}]; k); Table[a[n], {n, 1, 102}](* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 03 2012, after _R. J. Mathar_ *)
program: A038148(n) = factorback(apply(e -> A006047(e), factorint(n)[, 2])); \\ (After A037445) - _Antti Karttunen_, May 28 2017
results.author: _Yasutoshi Kohmoto_
ext: Data section further extended to 105 terms by _Antti Karttunen_, May 28 2017
